---1740643075-943151888-1321315008=:47868
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi,
=C2=A0 I'm not 100% sure to get the whole meaning of your question, so =
I might answer a bit off-target ^^

=C2=A0 In that paragraph about the taxo=
nomy (end of page 4), I mention "local information". It's not a gradient, a=
s in "gradient based optimization", that is, a clue on the local geometry o=
f the objective function. By "local information", I mean, *any* kind of loc=
al feedback of the behavior of the phenotype. If we optimize a plane wing, =
it could be, say, the local air pressure. If we optimize a heat exchanger, =
it would be local heath flux. If we optimize a water pipe network, it would=
 the local water flux and pressure.


=C2=A0Then, does this local informati=
on feeback turns "external non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved e=
mbryogeny" ? It's quite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say you dec=
ode the genotype as a transformation of an initial phenotype to a final one=
. You have many many ways to do this, and you can have genotype as a very f=
lexible transformation (many many development steps, each doing small chang=
es in all possible ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc tr=
ansformation step). So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" and "impli=
cit evolved embryogeny", I believe there is a whole gradient of possibiliti=
es rather than a sharp border between the two. Actually, to have a trully "=
implicit evolved embryogeny", it would unbounded development. But in practi=
ce, allowing a few steps of development brings a lot of flexibility for a g=
enotype, so it's a rethoritical remark.

Cheers,

Alex


__________________=
______________

=C3=80=C2=A0: neat@yah=
oogroups.com

Objet=C2=A0: Re: =
Re : Re : [neat] Any Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itsel=
f Is The Output?


=C2=A0 


Alex,
Thank you for the link! Question: In you=
r opinion, does the added presence of local gradient-based optimization of =
the design space transition the classification definition from "external no=
n-evolved embryogeny" to "implicit evolved embryogeny"? BTW, I am attracted=
 to your more flexible taxonomy, as I have never been fully comfortable wit=
h the spatial transformation constraint assumption.
Thanks,
Andy
